SUMMARY: MatA is a LuxR-type transcription factor that is directly involved, as a positive regulator acting at transcriptional and posttranscriptional levels, in expression of mat operon in meningitis isolate strain IHE 3034 [22422754]. On or hand, MatA controls expression of flhDC operon, with higher affinity to flhDp, repressing flagellum biosynsis, motility, and taxis [22422754]. opposite regulatory actions of MatA on mat and on flhDC promoters advance adaptation of E. coli from a planktonic to an adhesive lifestyle [22422754]. MatA binds more weakly to pfliA and to pfliC, and ir levels are equal to those observed for matB [22422754]. MatA exerts a dual regulatory function on choice of planktonic/sessile lifestyle and furr supports presence of antagonistic control of attachment and motility. MatA is tightly integrated into two separate regulatory circuits, H-NS-MatA-flhDC and RcsB-MatA-flhDC, both of which control expression of flagellum. MatA interferes with bacterial motility and flagellar synsis in meningitis-associated isolate IHE 3034 as well as K-12 strains of Escherichia coli [22422754].
